title: 1982–83 Rugby Football League season
text:
The 1982–83 <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League">Rugby Football League</a> season was the 88th ever season of professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> football in Britain. Sixteen teams competed from August, 1982 until May, 1983 for the <a href="Slalom%20Lager">Slalom Lager</a> <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League%20Championship">Championship</a>.
Season summary.
Hull finished on top of the First Division table to claim their sixth and, to date, last championship, but Widnes won the <a href="Rugby%20League%20Premiership">Rugby League Premiership</a> competition. Fulham, Wakefield Trinity, Salford and Whitehaven were promoted to the First Division.
<a href="Warrington%20Wolves">Warrington</a> beat <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St. Helens</a> 16–0 to win the <a href="RFL%20Lancashire%20Cup">Lancashire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a>, and <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> beat <a href="Bradford%20Bulls">Bradford Northern</a> 18–7 to win the <a href="RFL%20Yorkshire%20Cup">Yorkshire</a> <a href="Rugby%20league%20county%20cups">County Cup</a>.
League Tables.
Championship.
Final Standings
Challenge Cup.
The 1982-83 <a href="State%20Express%20555">State Express</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> was won by underdogs <a href="Featherstone%20Rovers">Featherstone Rovers</a> after defeating <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> 14-12 in the final.
The Final was played at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Wembley</a> before a crowd of 84,969.
Kangaroo Tour.
The months of October and November also saw the appearance of the <a href="Australian%20Kangaroos">Australian</a> team in England on their 1982 <a href="Kangaroo%20Tour">Kangaroo Tour</a>. Other than the three test <a href="The%20Ashes%20%28rugby%20league%29">Ashes series</a> against <a href="Great%20Britain%20Lions">Great Britain</a> (won 3–0 by Australia), The Kangaroos played and won matches against 9 Championship teams (Hull KR, Wigan, Barrow, St Helens, Leeds, Leigh, Bradford Northern, Hull and Widnes), 1 Second Division side (Fulham) and one county side (<a href="Cumbria%20rugby%20league%20team">Cumbria</a>).
The 1982 Kangaroos were coached by <a href="Frank%20Stanton%20%28rugby%20league%29">Frank Stanton</a> who had previously toured as a player in <a href="1963%E2%80%9364%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1963–64</a> and as coach of the <a href="1978%20Kangaroo%20tour%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20France">1978 Kangaroos</a>. The team captain was veteran <a href="Manly%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah</a> hooker <a href="Max%20Krilich">Max Krilich</a> who had also toured in 1978.
<a href="Souths%20Magpies">Souths Magpies</a> centre <a href="Mal%20Meninga">Mal Meninga</a>, making the first of a record 4 Kangaroo Tours as a player, was the leading point scorer on the tour with 166 from 10 tries and 68 goals including 48 points in the three Tests against Great Britain (2 tries, 21 goals). <a href="Manly%20Sea%20Eagles">Manly-Warringah</a> winger <a href="John%20Ribot">John Ribot</a> was the leading try scorer on the tour with 25.
The 1982 Kangaroos became known as The Invincibles after becoming the first team to go undefeated on a Kangaroo Tour.
